. Hi, had the same problem here, solved it by stripping out the "SEARCHING..."  string from rawdata by overriding getResult in TroubleCodesActivity.java :
java
public class ModifiedTroubleCodesObdCommand extends TroubleCodesObdCommand {
    @Override
    public String getResult() {
        // remove unwanted response from output since this results in erroneous error codes
        return rawData.replace("SEARCHING...", "");
        }
    }
and changing
java
TroubleCodesObdCommand tcoc = new TroubleCodesObdCommand();
tcoc.run(sock.getInputStream(), sock.getOutputStream());
result = tcoc.getFormattedResult();
to 
java
ModifiedTroubleCodesObdCommand tcoc = new ModifiedTroubleCodesObdCommand();
tcoc.run(sock.getInputStream(), sock.getOutputStream());
result = tcoc.getFormattedResult();
works for me ...

. you can clone obd-java-api it into your project folder:
git clone https://github.com/pires/obd-java-api.git
create obd-java-api/build.gradle with something like
apply plugin: 'java'
in main build.gradle change 
 compile 'pt.lighthouselabs.obd:obd-java-api:0.8' 
to
 compile project(':obd-java-api')
in settings.gradle add include ':obd-java-api'
that should do it
. we're on f-droid again with the new package name:
https://f-droid.org/repository/browse/?fdid=com.github.pires.obd.reader
note that for auto update to work in the future the tag name and android:versionName in the manifest must be absolutely identical (2.0-rc1 vs 2.0-RC1 ). 
for reference, any future modifications of the fdroid metadata can be made here: https://gitlab.com/fdroid/fdroiddata/blob/master/metadata/com.github.pires.obd.reader.txt

. @Pho3niX90 This is a really great resource! Unfortunately the bottom of the page states that all information on the page is strictly copyrighted, so we probably won't be able to just siphon off their data and feed it into the tool. They do permit linking, though – we could have each DTC open a link to their site (http://www.obd-codes.com/$DTC, replacing $DTC with the respective code).
As for brand-specific DTCs: obd-codes.com states that, of the P codes, only those beginning with P1 are manufacturer-specific. The same seems to be true for the C codes (the C0 codes appear to be generic, and they have a list of GM-specific codes starting with C1) and also of the U codes. The have no information on manufacturer-specific B codes, and all the codes they have start with B0. I'd suspect that, as with the others, any manufacturer-specific B codes would also start with B1.
The OpenOBD db has manufacturer and model fields but currently they are all set to "Generic".
About descriptions changing – different implementations may use different wordings, as in:
P0441 Tank Venting System Function (Android OBD-II Reader)
P0441 Evaporative Emission System Incorrect Purge Flow (OpenOBD)
P0441 Evaporative Emission Control System Incorrect Purge Flow (obd-codes.com)
However, these are all referring to the same thing, with some descriptions being a bit more specific than others. But I'd expect the meaning of the codes to be stable – at least for the generic codes (other than B1, C1, P1, U1). Or do you have examples where the meaning changed?
. @Pho3niX90 If it's not too late: a Sqlite DB could be translated as well if we included an extra column for language. The search key would then be DTC, make and language. The language field could be null for English descriptions, with some logic to fall back to that if no description is found in the current UI language.
It would take some extra coding: we'd initially need to determine the UI language. Then, on each lookup, we'd look for entries in that language, and if no result is found, repeat the search for the default language.
On the long run, I think a database is easier to maintain than a set of arrays.

sebaroesch:
As far as I understand, the current code does expect the BT adapter not to return any result for the command to reset the OBD BT adapter ("AT Z") and thus doesn´t read (and clear) the return buffer at all.
Since my adapter IS returning something for "AT Z" (the ELM version) this return value is still in the buffer, when the  returned value for the next command ("AT E0" in my example) is fetched. This causes kind of a chain reaction, so that the result stored for each command executed after "AT Z", is in fact the result of the preceeding command. And this, in turn, sometimes leads to a parsing error when calling getFormattedResult, since the result obviously has a different format than expected.

. Hello @KarthickCk ,
I was able to take a look at the issue. It seems that the problem was with the included obd-java-api library (https://github.com/pires/obd-java-api). 

The exception is thrown because the FuelType your vehicle returns is not included in the FuelType enumaration (https://github.com/spapas/obd-java-api/blob/master/src/main/java/pt/lighthouselabs/obd/enums/FuelType.java). I submitted a patch (https://github.com/pires/obd-java-api/pull/22) that checks for the NullPointerException and returns "-" instead of letting it propagate. However I believe that a better fix would be to find out why your vehicle returns a Fuel type that is not on the discussed list.
In any case, I don't know when my patch will be merged or when the patched version of obd-java-api will be included to the maven repository. If you want to use the patch, just get the patched version of obd-java-api and run mvn clean install. A .jar file will be created in the target directory. Copy the full path of that .jar file. After that, go to the build.gradle file of android-obd-reader and change line 
compile 'pt.lighthouselabs.obd:obd-java-api:0.6'
to
compile files('/Users/serafeim/progr/java/obd-java-api/target/obd-java-api-0.7-SNAPSHOT.jar')
It then should no longer throw the exception (but you will see a "-" for the fuel type).
. Hello @garvgarg. The ObdCommand class (and various others) belong to obd-java-api (https://github.com/pires/obd-java-api) as you can see in the line compile 'pt.lighthouselabs.obd:obd-java-api:0.7' of the file build.gradle
.

I tried researching more on DTC parsing with different possible protocols and found this: http://www.kbmsystems.net/files/Engine%20ECU%20Fault%20Code%20Reading%20with%20OBDKey.pdf
However, I'm still fuzzy on ELM327 and possible outputs - does the ELM327 have anything to do with the DTC response?  If it does not, then proper DTC parsing will depend if it's a CAN, or ISO response.  If it's CAN, then the first byte (after the header-type 43/47 first byte) is for how many DTC there are.  For ISO, the DTC code bytes are sent right away, but in frames with checksums under some conditions.  I'm trying to create an algorithm on how to correctly parse, but if I'm understanding the documentation correctly, the current code definitely needs quite a bit of work.  We might even need to know the protocol if it will help make the algorithm cleaner.  Of course, I could be wrong if someone can guide me on how to properly fix.

. One additional piece of information. The version I had downloaded before the summer did not have this issue. Is it possible that some changes have been inserted during the summer that influence this? I cannot find any relevant changes in the history but you never know. 
. One last note on this. I spent another couple of hours on this and I have found out (probably not surprisingly) that this happens when the reset command (and the rest of the initialisation) is either not sent by the app or received by the OBD Bluetooth reader. In this case the results are random. 
I could not identify why this happens: if it is just chance or if it is a structural problem. In any case it needs some fix (e.g. by double checking that if the init does not work it is repeated. 
I am reporting this in case anyone else has time to look into this, as I am unlikely to be able to do anything over the next several weeks. 
. I will try. Not sure however that is the cause.

. Yes I have done some further investigation and found something. I have realised (quite by chance) that there is one specific moment when you get the random results: when you turn off the engine and turn off the power but do not remove the key, the OBD dongle sends random values. I am unsure of why although I have an intuition that this is related to an imperfect switching off of the power (some functions are still active when the key is in, e.g the lights are kept on). 
Anyway I did an extensive test when I visited a friend. We drove for about 200km and I regularly tested the speed and rpm against the ones shown on the dashboard. They were all right. However when we stopped for petrol and my friend went to pay, I started getting random values. Speed went to 100km/h, rpm to 4000, etc.
I hope it helps

. then go ahead and use it

```
 StringBuilder b = new StringBuilder();
for (int i = 2; i < buffer.size(); i++) {
      b.append(new Character((char) buffer.get(i).intValue()).toString());
  }
String vin = b.toString().replaceAll("[\u0000-\u001f]", "");
```
See a complete solution here (parses those ":" separated vins and the other multiline one):
https://github.com/anti43/obd-java-api/blob/master/src/main/java/com/github/pires/obd/commands/control/VinObdCommand.java
for this to work properly the ObdCommand class needs changes aswell:
https://github.com/anti43/obd-java-api/blob/master/src/main/java/com/github/pires/obd/commands/ObdCommand.java#L165
as opposed to the solution in https://github.com/pires/obd-java-api/issues/54 this utilizes regex replace to avoid Indexoutofbounds and Nullpointer exceptions

https://www.scantool.net/support/index.php?_m=knowledgebase&_a=viewarticle&kbarticleid=32
ATE0 - Turn echo off. Characters sent to ElmScan are not retransmitted back to the host computer.
ATE1 - Turn echo on. This is the default state, characters are echoed back to the host computer.
ATH0 - Turn headers off. This is the default state, header information and CRC byte are omitted.
ATH1 - Turn headers on. Header information and CRC byte are displayed.
ATZ - Causes the chip to reset itself, as if the power was cycled off and then on again.

Hello again,
My ECUsim 2000 has 5 knobs which can be used to manually update the values of the parameters.
The parameters that can be monitored are:
- Knob 1: Engine Coolant Temperature;
- Knob 2: Engine Speed (RPM);
- Knob 3: Vehicle Speed;
- Knob 4: Oxygen Sensor Voltage (I don't know if this is actually available in the current API, didn't check);
- Knob 5: Mass Air Flow (MAF).
This simulator, also has a Configuration DIP Switch (has two switches that set the protocol attributes for ISO 15765-4(CAN). Switch number 1 is also used to select the init type for ISO 14230-4: 
a) 29 bit / 11 bit - Selects CAN frame ID type;
b) 500 kbps / 250 kbps - Selects CAN baud rate;
c) Fast Init / 5 Baud Init - Selects the type of initialization for ISO 14230-4).
When i wrote the previous message, i was using the simulator with the following settings: 
29 bit / Fast Init + 500kbps
With these settings, i was receiving those strange values for most of the parameters, to be more precise: Knob 1, Knob 2 and Knob 3.
Meanwhile, i changed to the following settings:
11 bit / 5 Baud Init + either 500 kbps or 250 kbps
After i did this, i ran the Android application once again and i've noticed that the values for Knob 1(Engine Coolant Temperature) and Knob 2(Engine Speed (RPM)) are displayed correctly. Knob 3(Vehicle Speed) is still the same strange format, though.
Currently, for Knob 3(Vehicle Speed) the displayed value is as follows:
- With Knob 3 set at max, the displayed value is: 410DFF2:0DFF4000103700
- With Knob 3 set at min, the displayed value is: 410D002:0D003000103700
Knob 3 should give as a returned value 0x00 for min and 0xFF for max (0~255km/h).

410DFF2:0DFF4000103700
